You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Data structures for Approximate Discrete Fréchet distance

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
A big open question is whether we can store P𝑃P in a data structure, for efficient (approximate) Fréchet distance queries for any query Q𝑄Q. This topic received considerable attention throughout the
years   [ref]28    .
A closely related field is nearest neighbor data structures under the Fréchet distance metric [ref]23   .
Recently at SODA 2023, Gudmundsson, Seybold and Wong  answer this question negatively for arbitrary curves in ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}: showing that even with polynomial preprocessing space and time, we cannot preprocess a curve P𝑃P to decide the Fréchet distance between P𝑃P and a query curve Q𝑄Q in Ω​((n​m)1−δ)Ωsuperscript𝑛𝑚1𝛿\Omega((nm)^{1-\delta}) time for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. Surprisingly, even in very restricted settings efficient results are difficult to obtain.
De Berg et al.  present an O​(n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(n^{2}) size
data structure that restricts the orientation of the query segment to be horizontal. Queries are supported in
O​(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n) time, and even subcurve queries are allowed (in that case, using
O​(n2​log2⁡n)𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript2𝑛O(n^{2}\log^{2}n) space). Recently at ESA 2022, Buchin et al.  improve these result to using only O​(n​log2⁡n)𝑂𝑛superscript2𝑛O(n\log^{2}n) space, where queries take O​(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n) time.
For arbitrary query segments, they present an O​(n4+δ)𝑂superscript𝑛4𝛿O(n^{4+\delta}) size data structure that supports (subcurve) queries to arbitrary segments in O​(log4⁡n)𝑂superscript4𝑛O(\log^{4}n) time. Gudmundsson et al.  extend de Berg et al.’s  data structure. First to subcurve queries with arbitrary start and end points, then to queries where the horizontal query segment is translated in order to minimize its Fréchet distance. By applying parametric search, they obtain a O​(n2​log2⁡n)𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript2𝑛O(n^{2}\log^{2}n) size data structure that performs the generalized subcurve queries in O​(log8⁡n)𝑂superscript8𝑛O(\log^{8}n) query time. With another application of parametric search, the data structure performs the translation-invariant Fréchet query in O​(log16⁡n)𝑂superscript16𝑛O(\log^{16}n) query time. Driemel and Har-peled  create a data structure to store any curve in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} for constant d𝑑d.
They preprocess P𝑃P in O​(n​log3⁡n)𝑂𝑛superscript3𝑛O(n\log^{3}n) time and O​(n​log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(n\log n) space. For any query (Q,ε,i,j)𝑄𝜀𝑖𝑗(Q,\varepsilon,i,j) they can create a (3+ε)3𝜀(3+\varepsilon)-approximation of Dℱ​(P​[i,j],Q)subscript𝐷ℱ𝑃𝑖𝑗𝑄{D_{\mathcal{F}}}(P[i,j],Q) in O​(m2​log⁡n​log⁡(m​log⁡n))𝑂superscript𝑚2𝑛𝑚𝑛O(m^{2}\log n\log(m\log n)) time. There exist some data structures for specifically the discrete Fréchet distance.
Driemel, Psarros and Schmidt  fix ε𝜀\varepsilon and an upper bound on m𝑚m beforehand (and assume m<<nmuch-less-than𝑚𝑛m<<n).
They store any curve P𝑃P in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} for constant d𝑑d using O​((m​log⁡1ε​ε−d)m)𝑂superscript𝑚1𝜀superscript𝜀𝑑𝑚O((m\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\varepsilon^{-d})^{m}) space and preprocessing, to answer (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)-approximate Fréchet distance queries in O​(m2+log⁡1ε)𝑂superscript𝑚21𝜀O(m^{2}+\log\frac{1}{\varepsilon}) time.
Filtser  gives the corresponding data structure for the discrete Fréchet distance.
